dialogue.statement: Hi there! I'm here to listen and learn more about what's on your mind. Feel free to share whatever you'd like, and we'll explore it together.
Hey, thanks for listening. I'm just super overwhelmed right now with this college situation and not sure what the right move is for me.
Balancing college decisions can indeed feel overwhelming. What aspects of the situation are weighing on you the most?
client(exploring): I guess it's the pressure from my family and the fear of making the wrong choice. I don't want to regret either staying or leaving.

statement.reasoning: The client's story is well-articulated, providing detailed context, thoughts, and feelings about the college situation and family pressures. Empathy and rapport have been established, with mutually acknowledged concerns. The goals of exploring appear met, indicating readiness to transition towards strengthening motivation and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It's understandable to feel caught between family expectations and your own fears. What would life look like if you made a choice that truly felt right for you?
client(reflecting): I think I'd feel more at peace, like I was taking control of my own path. But it's hard to know what that actually looks like without disappointing anyone.
Taking control of your path sounds empowering. What are some steps you might take that align with your values and bring you closer to that feeling of peace?

client(reflecting): I guess I could start by having an honest conversation with my family about what I really want. Maybe also taking some time to explore different career options before making any big commitments.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed the desire for control and peace by aligning their actions with their values. They've identified potential steps, like speaking with family and exploring career options. Change talk is present, and ambivalence has decreased. The client seems motivated toward a change goal, indicating readiness to develop a specific plan.

dialogue.statement: Having an honest conversation with your family and taking time to explore career options are meaningful steps. Considering your situation, possible goals could be setting a timeframe for your decision or identifying resources for career exploration. What small steps feel achievable for you right now?

client(choosing): I think I could definitely talk to my family soon and just be upfront about how I'm feeling. And maybe I can reach out to career services at school to see if they have any workshops or counseling that could help me figure things out.

Setting up a conversation with your family and reaching out to career services are great steps forward. To support you, we could establish a timeline for these actions. How about deciding when you'll have this conversation and when you'll reach out to career services? What feels manageable for you?

client(choosing): I think I could have the conversation with my family by this weekend, and I'll try to contact career services by next week. That way, I can start getting some clarity on my next steps.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified concrete actions and a timeline for addressing their situation, such as speaking with family and contacting career services, which aligns with creating a clear goal and action plan. Potential barriers have been discussed, and the client shows readiness to move forward. Confidence in their ability to manage these steps is evident, which suggests readiness for the next phase.

dialogue.statement: Having a conversation with your family by the weekend and reaching out to career services by next week sounds like a solid plan. You're taking proactive steps that align with the peace and control you're seeking. As you prepare for these conversations, remember that it's okay to express your feelings openly. This journey is about finding what feels right for you, and you're doing great by considering each step carefully. Whenever you feel unsure, I'm here to support you. How about we check in after you've had these conversations to see how things are progressing? Keep trusting yourself and the process, you're making strides towards your goals.

client(terminating): Thanks, I appreciate your help. I'll definitely check back in after I've talked to them and see how things are unfolding. It's nice to know I've got someone to talk this through with.

statement.reasoning: The session has outlined specific next steps for the client, including a plan to have discussions with family and contact career services. The client has agreed to check back in, indicating a closure to this session.

concern:
title: I need advice on dropping out, please help
So my dad just got approved for ssdi, I (18 F) qualify for $900 a month if I'm at least part time enrolled in school. Well, it took my dad a long time to get approved so I thought that once he got approved I could apply to a college and then start getting money pretty quick. Apparently thats not how it works, my dad has to get processed too. Now because no one told me that, (only how he had been accepted after waiting like a year or two already) and I was being pressured to start college for other reasons, I started looking at potential colleges. My grandmother found a pretty nice one and texted me one day to come over to her house and we would look at the school and see how we like it. Well when I got there she already had all the information typed out on the application form for a degree I never wanted in the first place. If it were up to me, I wouldn't have even gone to school in the first place. But it wasn't, I knew how much it meant to my other grandmother (I will be referring to her as Nana). I had already decided that with the "free money" (I say that very lightly lol) and my Nanas eagerness for me to start school, that I would do it, I just wanted to wait a little bit. Well, I thought I had mentioned my unwillingness enough times to stick. I already have a few job offers I could take for the summer this year if I really wanted to. Anyway, I asked my grandmother if I had to do this. She told me I had too. So obviously I thought her and Nana had talked it out and they determined I had to start right away, which was the only reason why I caved in. So I accepted and she called Nana and they paid. When I got home that night, my Nana and Dada (primary caregivers/parental figures) asked me if this is what I wanted. I told them this: "No, but it's something I have to do" referring back to what my grandmother had said previously. Well, here I am a few days later and I just now got off the phone with my Nana who told me she had no idea and that she was never gonna force me to go to college, as well as it would take until the end of the year most likely before I would receive the ssdi benefits and none of which would include money I would have made if I was getting paid as soon as I started school. So now I'm at a crossroads, I never wanted to start school in the first place because I was scared I would give up halfway through or change my mind and switch majors. I wanted to wait and plan everything out and not jump right in. I jumped right into work right after high school and worked myself sick, I didn't wanna repeat that. Tomorrow i think, is the deadline to ask for our money back. I don't wanna be labeled a college dropout. The mere thought of it makes me want to cry tbh. I know that this is mostly my fault for not checking in with both parties. Most of the time they do consult each other about my school so I just assumed they both knew everything. Now I have no idea what to do, I have less than 24 hours to figure out if I drop out and get the money back, or switch majors which will still leave me with the same issue because I have no idea what I want to do. I'm open to hear what literally anyone has to say.
